content.raw:
@{557058:434ecab2-e510-4ede-8f9a-1c2a5a4032e1} Do you mind if I ask why this is the only test using DART? Is DART even required if it is going to be used in only one test?  
  
EDIT: I’ve just remember that DART doesn’t work on WheelTracked. It is ok to leave it.
content.html:
@Martin Pecka Do you mind if I ask why this is the only test using DART? Is DART even required if it is going to be used in only one test?

EDIT: I’ve just remember that DART doesn’t work on WheelTracked. It is ok to leave it.

content.raw: yeah, none of the test cases are using DART. I see that there is some dart code in the GetCategoryBits function, but I'm not sure if that is needed if there are no tests using dart
content.html: yeah, none of the test cases are using DART. I see that there is some dart code in the GetCategoryBits function, but I'm not sure if that is needed if there are no tests using dart

content.raw: You’re right, the DART code does nothing here. I’ll remove it tomorrow.
content.html: You’re right, the DART code does nothing here. I’ll remove it tomorrow.

content.raw: I understand why he is testing in this case, I recommend to use [Gazebo’s collision](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1physics_1_1Collision.html) class which is physic engine independent to compare two collisions, I don’t know if it is strictly necessary to use `CategoryBits` for that purpose.
content.html: I understand why he is testing in this case, I recommend to use Gazebo’s collision class which is physic engine independent to compare two collisions, I don’t know if it is strictly necessary to use CategoryBits for that purpose.

content.raw: It’s been a long time since I developed the code, but I faintly remember that using CategoryBits directly was because of bug [#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1855/gazebo-misuses-collision-collide-bits-as](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1855/gazebo-misuses-collision-collide-bits-as) .
content.html: It’s been a long time since I developed the code, but I faintly remember that using CategoryBits directly was because of bug #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1855/gazebo-misuses-collision-collide-bits-as .

content.raw:
_Since this feature hasn’t been merged \(yet\) I am going to ask a support question here, let me know if I should open a new issue instead._

I understand this was presented on IROS, thus I assume this plugin can also be used with ROS. Is there a ROS wrapper available for this plugin?

Kind regards, Tim
content.html:
Since this feature hasn’t been merged (yet) I am going to ask a support question here, let me know if I should open a new issue instead.

I understand this was presented on IROS, thus I assume this plugin can also be used with ROS. Is there a ROS wrapper available for this plugin?

Kind regards, Tim

content.raw: Hi Tim. There’s no explicit ROS wrapper for this plugin, but of course you can use it. It’s just about writing a layer that translates ROS cmd\_vel to Gazebo cmd\_vel \(since this plugin is controlled via cmd\_vel commands if I remember correctly\). That should be pretty straight-forward, and once this plugin is merged, it’s possible such a gazebo\_ros plugin will appear :wink:
content.html: Hi Tim. There’s no explicit ROS wrapper for this plugin, but of course you can use it. It’s just about writing a layer that translates ROS cmd_vel to Gazebo cmd_vel (since this plugin is controlled via cmd_vel commands if I remember correctly). That should be pretty straight-forward, and once this plugin is merged, it’s possible such a gazebo_ros plugin will appear

content.raw:
Why did you use Pose for cmd\_vel topic? It seems strange to me that I can't set angular speed value to more than `pi==3.14...` because if I write higher value to Quaternion.Z, it becomes negative \(`3.54 == pi + 0.4` extracts from Quaternion to `-pi+0.4 ==-2.74`\).

[#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2b59492f96fcf121b33f290fd5cf0b70b42f4e22/plugins/TrackedVehiclePlugin.cc#lines-180](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2b59492f96fcf121b33f290fd5cf0b70b42f4e22/plugins/TrackedVehiclePlugin.cc#lines-180)

I know I can set greater value to tracksSeparation or lesser steerEfficiency in order to get greater value of angular component in track velocity, but it seems like hacking while sudden change of angular speed direction around `pi` value seems like bug.

Am I right or did I just missed something?

Upd: I believe more customizable implementation could be done if subclasses of TrackedVehiclePlugin would set their tracks value not via `SetTrackVelocityImpl()` but through subscription on `tracksVelocityPub` . Then if one would get more tricky control over tracks they could post track velocity values right in `tracksVelocityPub` without any intermediate calculations.

‌

Anyway, thank you for doing this pull request.
content.html:
Why did you use Pose for cmd_vel topic? It seems strange to me that I can't set angular speed value to more than pi==3.14... because if I write higher value to Quaternion.Z, it becomes negative (3.54 == pi + 0.4 extracts from Quaternion to -pi+0.4 ==-2.74).

#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2b59492f96fcf121b33f290fd5cf0b70b42f4e22/plugins/TrackedVehiclePlugin.cc#lines-180

I know I can set greater value to tracksSeparation or lesser steerEfficiency in order to get greater value of angular component in track velocity, but it seems like hacking while sudden change of angular speed direction around pi value seems like bug.

Am I right or did I just missed something?

Upd: I believe more customizable implementation could be done if subclasses of TrackedVehiclePlugin would set their tracks value not via SetTrackVelocityImpl() but through subscription on tracksVelocityPub . Then if one would get more tricky control over tracks they could post track velocity values right in tracksVelocityPub without any intermediate calculations.

‌

Anyway, thank you for doing this pull request.

content.raw:
You’re completely right this was a bad choice. It was probably because there’s no Twist message in Gazebo defined yet. 

@{557058:5de38267-b118-494c-aa76-4fab35448816} @{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} Is it okay to add a message similar to `geometry_msgs::Twist` from ROS? And can I change it in the plugin API for Gazebo 9, or should I retain the old \(wrong?\) topic type and add a new one with Twist type?
content.html:
You’re completely right this was a bad choice. It was probably because there’s no Twist message in Gazebo defined yet.

@Steve Peters @Louise Poubel Is it okay to add a message similar to geometry_msgs::Twist from ROS? And can I change it in the plugin API for Gazebo 9, or should I retain the old (wrong?) topic type and add a new one with Twist type?

content.raw: There's a [twist message](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/ign-msgs3/proto/ignition/msgs/twist.proto) on `ign-msgs3`. We could backport the message to `ign-msgs1`, which is  the version Gazebo 9 depends on. We shouldn't break the current behaviour, since this plugin has already been released. So the new topic should be added in a backwards compatible way.
content.html: There's a twist message on ign-msgs3. We could backport the message to ign-msgs1, which is the version Gazebo 9 depends on. We shouldn't break the current behaviour, since this plugin has already been released. So the new topic should be added in a backwards compatible way.

content.raw: Backporting the message would be nice. But I’m confused, since there are message definitions in both [#!/osrf/gazebo/src/gazebo9/gazebo/msgs/](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/gazebo9/gazebo/msgs/) and [https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/ign-msgs1/proto/ignition/msgs/](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/ign-msgs1/proto/ignition/msgs/) . How do they work together in Gazebo 9?
content.html: Backporting the message would be nice. But I’m confused, since there are message definitions in both #!/osrf/gazebo/src/gazebo9/gazebo/msgs/ and https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/ign-msgs1/proto/ignition/msgs/ . How do they work together in Gazebo 9?

content.raw: There should be no conflict between the messages, because they're in different namespaces. And since they're all protobuf messages, they should work equally with `gazebo::transport` and `ignition::transport`. Looking quickly through the code, I think we only have examples of `gazebo::transport` + `gazebo::msgs` and `ignition::transport` + `ignition::msgs` though.
content.html: There should be no conflict between the messages, because they're in different namespaces. And since they're all protobuf messages, they should work equally with gazebo::transport and ignition::transport. Looking quickly through the code, I think we only have examples of gazebo::transport + gazebo::msgs and ignition::transport + ignition::msgs though.

content.raw: Ok. So should I prepare a PR that would backport the Twist message to the gazebo repo?
content.html: Ok. So should I prepare a PR that would backport the Twist message to the gazebo repo?

content.raw: Adding the message to `gazebo::msgs` is probably the easiest path forward :thumbsup:
content.html: Adding the message to gazebo::msgs is probably the easiest path forward

content.html: Fixed in #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3116/added-cmd_vel_twist-control-topic-to .
